newsitem.title: GERMANY: German SPD leaders fall for bogus Blair party.
newsitem.headline: German SPD leaders fall for bogus Blair party.

text.p: Three leading German politicians accepted a bogus "invitation" to an election victory party for British Prime Minister Tony Blair that was to take place on Sunday in London, a German satirical magazine said on Sunday.

The Frankfurt-based "Titanic" magazine said Oskar Lafontaine, chairman of the Social Democrats (SPD), along with SPD leaders Gerhard Schroeder and Rudolf Scharping agreed by telephone to attend the non-existent party.
A Titanic reporter called Martin Sonneborn, speaking English, posed as "Mr. Burlington, head of the celebration committee of the Labour Party," the magazine said.
"All three said they would be delighted to attend," Titanic said. The SPD even put out a press release last week saying Lafontaine would attend the party, but withdrew it a day later.

The magazine said all three were asked to bring an instrument in order to take part in "a victory jam session" with Blair, who would play an electric guitar, and Bill Clinton, who they were told would bring his saxophone.
"I can't play anything," Schroeder told the magazine. "I can't even sing." But he added: "I will come gladly, very gladly. I like you guys."
Gerhard Schroeder, premier of the state of Lower Saxony, is a top candidate to challenge Chancellor Helmut Kohl in next year's general elections.

Scharping, whom Kohl defeated in 1994, said he would bring a percussion instrument to play. But Scharping insisted that he be allowed to play in the front row next to Blair because Scharping is "president of the Social Democrats of Europe."
